@jtattermusch The build seems to be red partly because this PR is broken and partly due to flaky tests. I am about to upload a fix for the PR brokenness. Here is my understanding of how it's broken and an appropriate way to fix it:

This PR currently breaks the `tools/run_tests/sanity/check_sources_and_headers.py` check: The `grpc++_base` filegroup (or target, as this script calls it in its error output) has files that `#include` stuff from the `grpc_base` filegroup.

I tried to fix this by just adding a `deps` dependency from the `grpc++_base` filegroup to the `grpc` lib. This works for the `libgrpc++.a` target, but that pulls in ssl stuff into the `grpc++_unsecure` target and breaks it with duplicate symbols.

I tried to fix that by changing the added `deps` dependency from `grpc` to `grpc_base`, but that is not valid because `grpc_base` is not a `lib`.

---

So: The `check_sources_and_headers.py` script requires that `grpc++_base` has a `uses` or a `deps` dependency to `grpc_base`. Because of the reasons outlined in the initial PR comment, it can't be a `uses` dependency. Because `grpc_base` is a filegroup and not a lib, it can't be a `deps` dependency either. A `deps` dependency could point to `grpc` instead, which makes the `grpc++` target work but it breaks the `grpc++_unsecure` target.

I think a good way to fix this is to make `grpc_base` a lib instead of a filegroup. That way, both secure and `*_unsecure` targets can depend on it, and the `grpc++`/`grpc++_unsecure` targets can depend on it without pulling in all the `gprc_base` .o files in their static library outputs, which causes duplicate symbol errors. Furthermore, this change makes the build more similar to how the Bazel `BUILD` file is structured, where everything is a lib.

---

Another note: The `grpc++_cronet` target is broken in master too, because of essentially the same reasons as `grpc++`. The new commits that I'm just pushing fixes `grpc++_cronet` too.
Thanks for your pull request. The automated tests will run as soon as one of the admins verifies this change is ok for us to run on our infrastructure.

Thanks for the PR. See my responses inline.

On Thu, May 11, 2017 at 11:24 PM, Per Grön <notifications@github.com> wrote:

> Here comes a very very small PR (except for generated code, the relevant
> changes are in build.yaml) with a very very long description. I'm sorry
> about the wordiness, but I don't know how to briefly explain this given
> that I am not familiar with this code base and don't know the person who
> will review this. For a brief description, refer to the commit messages.
>
> As far as I can tell, the CMakeFiles.txt (and probably Makefile and VS
> solution) files generated by the build.yaml processing are broken in the
> following way: The build files are syntactically correct, and they describe
> a build that can be built, but the resulting C++ libraries (grpc++,
> grpc++_cronet) are unusable.
>
> One way to see that something fishy is going on is to look at the current
> CMakeLists.txt file and observe that many files, for example
> src/core/lib/channel/channel_args.c are listed as part of several
> libraries. More precisely, all files in the grpc_base "filegroup" are
> listed several times.
>
> The libraries that contain src/core/lib/channel/channel_args.c are: grpc,
> grpc_cronet, grpc_test_util, grpc_unsecure, grpc++, grpc++_cronet and
> grpc++_unsecure.
>
In case of grpc, grpc_cronet and grpc_unsecure this is intended. These
libraries are basically different flavors or the gRPC C core library.

I agree that for others (specifically the C++ libraries) this is
questionable. For the grpc_test_utils it probably doesn't matter because
it's not a public library, it only there to make it easier to build tests.


> Listing implementation files in more than one CMake target is not really
> normal, but it is in itself not really an issue. However, there are also
> CMake statements like this:
>
> target_link_libraries(grpc++
>   ...
>   grpc
>   ...
> )
>
> There are similar ones for the other C++ libraries.
>
> What this does is that it tells CMake that whenever someone who actually
> wants to use grpc++ and does so with target_link_libraries(my_awesome_app
> grpc++), it should link not only against libgrpc++.a but also against
> libgrpc.a (and its dependencies).
>
> But libgrpc++.a and libgrpc.a are both linked with channel_args.o, so
> when my_awesome_app is linked it will fail with a duplicate symbol error.
>
> Now, this is not only a problem with that CMake links two things that
> aren't actually intended to be linked at the same time: Even if the
> settings are changed so that my_awesome_app is linked only with
> libgrpc++.a, the build will fail because my_awesome_app depends on
> symbols from src/core/lib/surface/init.c, but that actually is not
> present in the grpc++ target.
>
> So: When gRPC is built with the provided CMakeLists.txt, it will create
> libgrpc++.a and libgrpc.a. Some symbols are in both of them, some symbols
> (stuff from init.c) are only in libgrpc.a and the C++ stuff is only in
> libgrpc++.a. Short of some serious messing around with these static
> libraries there is nothing I can do to use them, they are just wrong.
> ------------------------------
>
> I've looked at build.yaml and the associated Python code, and at the BUILD
> file (which does not seem autogenerated) and tried to understand the
> situation. What I have found is:
>
>    - The build.yaml file has a "filegroup" concept that is a little bit
>    like a library in that it is a group of files with dependencies, but it
>    does not correspond to an actual build target.
>    - The BUILD file does not have "filegroups"; most of the build.yaml
>    filegroups are declared as grpc_cc_library()s.
>    - It seems like the intention is that programs using C++ gRPC should
>    need to link against SSL, Protobuf and gpr separately.
>    - I can't tell if the intention is that programs using C++ gRPC should
>    need to link against both libgrpc++.a and libgrpc.a or only libgrpc++.a
>
> I think programs that are using gRPC C++ should link against both
libgrpc++ and libgrpc.


>
> Based on this, I have concluded that I believe that it is not against what
> the authors of this system intended to make it so that programs using C++
> gRPC should need to link against both libgrpc++.a and libgrpc.a.
>
> Given that belief, I think the line in build.yaml that states that the
> grpc++_base filegroup should use (aka include) grpc_base is wrong. It is
> sufficient that the lib entries in that file say that the things that have
> the grpc++_base filegroup depend (as in target_link_libraries in CMake)
> on grpc.
>
> Removing that one line from build.yaml makes the generated CMakeLists.txt
> file have far fewer duplicates, and (more importantly) makes it possible
> for my CMake based application to use gRPC.
>

I think you are right in terms of removing grpc_base from shouldn't be part
of grpc++_base - so removing the 'uses' is correct. I am less convinced
about other changes being done in this PR (what does it fix to change
grpc_base from a filegroup to a library?) AFAIK, grpc_base is defined as a
filegroup to avoid having grpc_base library generated by the makefile.

test this please

@jtattermusch Thanks a bunch for the review!

For my purposes, the ["uses" change](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/pull/11097/commits/627d2973f75500a818ef294bf842a0d3728c1f3e) itself is enough.

As you say, this PR changes the makefiles to generate a `libgrpc_base.a` static library (which applications must link against). For my purposes, since CMake keeps track of these dependencies, it doesn't matter but I totally understand if you don't want it.

The reason I did the additional changes is that the `tools/run_tests/sanity/check_sources_and_headers.py` script, which is run as part of your CI tests, breaks if only the `uses` line is removed, because the `grpc++_base` filegroup has dependencies to files in `grpc_base` and without the `uses` line, they become undeclared dependencies, which that script prohibits.

Making `grpc_base` a library was the way I could come up with that silences that error. Do you have any other suggestions for how this can be fixed?

Idea: I could make a `grpc_base_headers` filegroup, and add it to `uses` of grpc_base and `grpc++_base`. I think that could silence the errors. What do you think?

I'll rebase once I know what to do.

Actually, the problem with "uses" and symbol duplication was already fixed properly here: https://github.com/grpc/grpc/pull/11247/files

Thanks for the PR anyway!
